newsitem.title: JAPAN: Softbank, News in wrangle with Asahi shareholders.
newsitem.headline: Softbank, News in wrangle with Asahi shareholders.

text.p: Asahi National Broadcasting Co (TV Asahi) said on Thursday that it would not accept board members from Softbank Corp and Australia's News Corp, two of its biggest shareholders, due to requests from other shareholders.
A TV Asahi spokesman said other big shareholders want Softbank and News Corp to confirm in a written statement that they would refrain from purchasing further shares of TV Asahi.
The shareholders also want the two firms to agree that they would not be involved in management of the company.
TV Asahi originally planned to accept the two part-time board members from Softbank News Corp Media, a joint venture between Softbank and News, at a shareholders' meeting on November 7.
Earlier this year, Softbank and News jointly acquired a 21.4 percent stake in TV Asahi through Japanese media company Obunsha Media, becoming the third largest shareholder at TV Asahi.

News Corp then sought to appoint John McBride, head of News Corp's Japan unit, as an executive at TV Asahi, but was rejected by TV Asahi on the grounds that Japanese law forbids foreigners from assuming executive posts at Japanese broadcasting companies.
Softbank and News have said the acquisition of stakes in TV Asahi was aimed at building a friendly business relationship with the company.
